thread.title: Jackie Evancho calls for Trump to reexamine transgender rights
thread.title_full: Jackie Evancho calls for Trump to reexamine transgender rights - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Jackie Evancho calls for Trump to reexamine transgender rights
text:
The young woman who belted out the national anthem at the Presidential Inauguration is hoping Trump will listen to her concerns about transgender rights.
Jackie Evancho, 16, appeared on "Good Morning America" Thursday along with her transgender sister Juliet hoping that the POTUS will meet with them to better understand the issues facing transgender people every day.
The sisters' plea comes after the Trump administration rolled back federal guidelines that called for allowance of transgender students to use whichever school bathroom matched their gender identity.
Jackie Evancho and her transgender sister Juliet speak on Good Morning America in response to President Trump's transgender rights roll back. (GMA) Juliet, 18, told George Stephanopoulos about how she faces discrimination all the time and she shared that not being allowed to use the bathroom of her choice was "unsafe and unhealthy."
Singer Jackie Evancho faces backlash over transgender sister 
"Donald Trump needs to know that being in such an unsafe environment won't do any good, not only for the transgender and the LGBT community, but as well everyone as a whole," Juliet — who came out as transgender in 2015 — explained.
Juliet and two other students filed a federal discrimination lawsuit against the Pine-Richland school district in Pennsylvania in October 2016 after the school decided to reverse the longstanding policy that allowed students to choose the restrooms that match their identities, according to Lambda Legal, the national LGBT advocacy organization, which filed the lawsuit on the students' behalf.
Jackie Evancho sang the national anthem at President Trump's inauguration on Jan. 20. (CARLOS BARRIA/REUTERS) It is unclear where the lawsuit stands now, but Juliet said during the interview that her school has been protective and supportive of her.
Months after the lawsuit was filed, Juliet's school nominated her as homecoming queen, "showing that they know, accept and respect me for who I am. So, why can't everyone else? Why make an issue where there isn't one?" she said in the filing .
Jackie Evancho ‘disappointed’ in Trump over transgender rights 
Once news broke of Trump’s decision, Jackie instantly tweeted at the POTUS , requesting a meeting.
Singer Jackie Evancho (left) poses with sister Juliet in 2015.  (Evan Agostini/Evan Agostini/Invision/AP) “@realDonaldTrump u gave me the honor 2 sing at your inauguration. Pls give me & my sis the honor 2 meet with u 2 talk #transgender rghts,” she wrote.
The “America’s Got Talent” alum told Stephanopoulus she hasn’t ruled out singing again either.
“The reason why I did sing for the inauguration was not for politics, it was for the honor and the privilege for my country,” she explained. “And that will stay the same.”
